item.title: Food Habits of the Barn Owl in the Southern Interior of British Columbia
item.description: Linda M. Van Damme and Mark Nyhof Abstract The diet of the Barn Owl (Tyto alba) in the south-central interior of British Columbia was determined from analysis of 1,424 prey remains recovered from 692 pellets collected between 1990 and 1997. Small mammals, principally rodents, were the main prey accounting for 96.4% of all remains. The meadow vole (Microtus pennsylvanicus) was the primary prey accounting for 95.3% of the owl’s diet. Secondary prey included birds (3.
